title: Set theoretic solution for the tuning problem
author: Vsevolod Deriushkin (newtonality.net)
relevance_why: The paper offers insights into mathematical frameworks to quantify musical consonance, which can be applied in audio generation and enhancement tools by providing a basis for more harmonically balanced sound synthesis.
background: The work explores mathematical definitions of musical consonance and proposes a novel tuning system that enhances the tuning of musical instruments.
contribution: This paper introduces a set-theoretic approach to generalize Just Intonation to inharmonic timbres while unifying spectral interference and harmonicity, achieving measurable consonance.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Earlier methods primarily focused on empirical and subjective judgments of consonance without a unified mathematical representation.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work quantifies consonance through two measurable metrics (affinity and harmonicity), which can dynamically generate sets of musical intervals.

key_innovation: The use of set theory to create a mathematical framework that quantifies consonance, thus facilitating a more systematic approach to tuning.
real_world_impact: This innovative tuning approach could lead to the development of musical instruments and sound synthesis tools that are capable of creating more harmonically rich and pleasing sounds.
limitations: No limitations are explicitly mentioned in the paper.

new_terms.affinity: **Affinity** refers to the measure of how closely a set of musical intervals aligns with perceived consonance.
new_terms.harmonicity: **Harmonicity** indicates the degree to which a sound or group of sounds is perceived as forming a harmonious relationship.
